title: Lung-DDPM: Semantic Layout-guided Diffusion Models for Thoracic CT Image Synthesis
author: Yifan Jiang (Centre de recherche du CHU de Quebec-Université Laval), Yannick Lemarechal (Quebec Heart & Lung Institute Research Center), Josée Bafaro (Quebec Heart & Lung Institute Research Center), Jessica Abi-Rjeile (Quebec Heart & Lung Institute Research Center), Philippe Joubert (Quebec Heart & Lung Institute Research Center), Philippe Després (Quebec Heart & Lung Institute Research Center), Venkata Manem (Centre de recherche du CHU de Quebec-Université Laval)
background: Generating high-fidelity synthetic thoracic computed tomography (CT) images using diffusion models guided by anatomical layouts to improve lung nodule segmentation.
contribution: This paper introduces Lung-DDPM, a diffusion model-based approach that generates realistic synthetic thoracic CT images informed by anatomical layouts to enhance the performance of lung nodule segmentation tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods faced challenges with anatomical imprecision, imperfect blending of lung and extra-pulmonary areas, and inconsistencies between adjacent slices.
technical_comparison.novelty: Lung-DDPM uses an anatomically aware sampling process to blend reference images seamlessly, improving anatomical fidelity and consistency across slices.

key_innovation: The method dynamically blends synthetic and reference images during the image generation process, ensuring high-quality results that maintain anatomical accuracy.
real_world_impact: Enhances data availability for training deep learning models in medical imaging, which can potentially improve lung cancer detection rates and patient outcomes.
limitations: The method relies on having accurate simple lung nodule annotations, which may still require manual input or advanced pre-processing techniques.

new_terms.Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models: **Denoising diffusion probabilistic models** are a class of generative models that iteratively refine noise into data while maintaining probabilistic properties, allowing for high-quality image generation.
new_terms.Frechet Inception Distance (FID): **Frechet Inception Distance** is a metric used to assess the quality of synthetic images by comparing the distribution of features derived from real and generated images.

open_sourcing: The code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/Manem-Lab/Lung-DDPM/
